name: Aretha Franklin
description:
'''Aretha Louise Franklin''' ({{IPAc-en|ə|'|r|iː|θ|ə}} {{respell|ə|REE|thə}}; March 25, 1942 – August 16, 2018) was an American singer, songwriter and pianist. Honored as the "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Queen of Soul]]", she was twice named by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine as the [[Rolling Stone's 200 Greatest Singers of All Time|greatest singer of all time]].

As a child, Franklin was noticed for her [[Gospel music|gospel]] singing at [[New Bethel Baptist Church (Detroit, Michigan)|New Bethel Baptist Church]] in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], where her father [[C. L. Franklin]] was a minister. At the age of 18, she was signed as a recording artist for [[Columbia Records]]. While her career did not immediately flourish, Franklin found acclaim and commercial success once she signed with [[Atlantic Records]] in 1966. There, she recorded significant hit albums such as ''[[I Never Loved a Man the Way I Love You]]'', ''[[Lady Soul]]'' and ''[[Aretha Now]]'' in the late 1960s and ''[[Young, Gifted and Black]]'', ''[[Amazing Grace (Aretha Franklin album)|Amazing Grace]]'' and ''[[Sparkle (soundtrack)|Sparkle]]'' in the 1970s, before experiencing problems with the record company. Franklin left Atlantic in 1979 and signed with [[Arista Records]], where her career was revised with the hit albums ''[[Jump to It]]'', ''[[Who's Zoomin' Who?]]'', ''[[Aretha (1986 album)|Aretha]]'' and ''[[A Rose Is Still a Rose]]''.

Franklin is [[List of best selling music artists|one of the best-selling music artists]], with more than 75 million records sold worldwide. She charted 112 singles on the US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' charts, including 73 [[Billboard Hot 100|Hot 100]] entries, 17 top-ten pop singles, 96 [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] entries and 20 number-one R&B singles. While her rendition of "[[Respect (song)#Aretha Franklin version|Respect]]" has been referred to as her [[signature song]], Franklin is known for other hit singles such as "[[(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman]]", "[[Chain of Fools]]", "[[Think (Aretha Franklin song)|Think]]", "[[I Say a Little Prayer#Aretha Franklin version|I Say a Little Prayer]]", "[[Rock Steady (Aretha Franklin song)|Rock Steady]]", "[[Day Dreaming (Aretha Franklin song)|Day Dreaming]]", "[[Freeway of Love]]" and "[[I Knew You Were Waiting (For Me)]]" (a duet with [[George Michael]]), to name a few. She also made a featured appearance in the 1980 musical-comedy film ''[[The Blues Brothers (film)|The Blues Brothers]]''.

Franklin received numerous honors throughout her career. She  won 18 [[Grammy Awards]] out of 44 nominations, including the first eight awards given for [[Grammy Award for Best Female R&B Vocal Performance|Best Female R&B Vocal Performance]] (1968–1975), as well as a [[Grammy Legend Award|Grammy Living Legend Award]] and [[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award|Lifetime Achievement Award]]. She was also awarded the [[National Medal of Arts]] and the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]]. In 1987, she became the first female artist to be inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]. Her other inductions include the [[UK Music Hall of Fame]] in 2005, the [[Gospel Music Hall of Fame]] in 2012, and posthumously the [[National Women's Hall of Fame]] in 2020. In 2019, the [[Pulitzer Prize]] jury awarded her a posthumous [[Pulitzer Prize Special Citations and Awards|special citation]] "for her indelible contribution to American music and culture for more than five decades".
